text: Frank Sherwood "Sherry" Rowland (June 28, 1927 â€“ March 10, 2012) was an American Nobel Prize-winning chemist. He was a professor of chemistry at the University of California, Irvine. His research was on atmospheric chemistry and chemical kinetics. His best-known work was the discovery that chlorofluorocarbons role in ozone depletion. He won the 1995 Nobel Prize in Chemistry with Mario Molina and Paul J. Crutzen. Rowland worked as a professor at the University of California, Irvine. Rowland died on March 10, 2012 in Newport Beach, California from problems caused by Parkinson's disease, aged 84. ==References== Category:1927 births Category:2012 deaths Category:American chemists Category:Scientists from Ohio Category:Scientists from California Category:Deaths from Parkinson's disease
title: F. Sherwood Rowland
